Tips.Well Formed: When creating your user stories, make sure that there is a Role, an Action and a Benefit - and that these match with each other! Reread the context carefully when you are unsure of the possible matches.
Tips.Atomic: Your user stories should tackle only one issue at a time. Hint: search for the word 'and' within either an action or a benefit, for this work usually refers to multiple problems within one user story - therefore not atomic!
Tips.Minimal: Your user stories should contain only a role, an action and a benefit. Additional information such as examples and extra descriptions make your  story not minimal.
Tips.Problem Oriented: Always check if your user stories only specify problems, not solutions. References to technologies, programs, or resources generally indicate your story is not problem oriented!
Tips.Full Sentence: Check if your user story is a grammatically correct sentence in English. Avoid partial sentences without subject or verb.
Tips.Unambiguous: Your written user stories should prevent multiple interpretations. Are there phrases or words like 'things', 'the duties', 'to manage' that are too vague and could mean anything? Then the user story is not unambiguous!
Tips.Independent: Make sure that your user stories stand on their own. Pointers towards other artifacts (e.g., 'please see user story 8' or 'check the pdf') make your user story not independent!
